byline.original: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM and SHARON OTTERMAN

abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has never been a churchgoer, has unexpectedly become an advocate for religion in the most public of arenas; from including time for prayers in prekindergarten classes to siding with ultra-Orthodox Jews in oversight of circumcision, de Blasio has pitted himself against some of his own allies, who criticize him for his sharp redefining of separation between church and state.
lead_paragraph: In finding new ways to commingle church and state, Bill de Blasio has carved himself a niche as a liberal who is willing to embrace religious groups rather than treat them as adversaries.

headline.main: Mayor de Blasio Emerges as an Unexpected Champion of Religion
headline.print_headline: New York City’s Unlikely Voice for Religion: A Secular Mayor
